text:
I’m pretty convinced consistency is generally opposed to virtue 

rather have people doing things that are good, because they feel it is good, rather than people doing bad they can rationalize 

That’s not to say the pursuit of consistency is bad..

so what I’m thinking is that:

- belief systems are fine
- live according to virtue, even if it strays from the belief system 
- updating the belief system according to virtue in a consistent way is good
 
but updating for the sake of making consistent -> trouble

let’s assume someone starts with a belief system, wlog, the legal system

Over time discrepancies between good and legal will become apparent to a person 

bad: updating “good” based on the law (this is consistent)
good(?): updating internal belief based on good

right I've been thinking about what this says about my ontology

Good is observable but unknowable in any precise way;

if you attempt to codify it, you'll wander away from any local/global maximas 

Virtue is individual, subjective, everchanging—yet it exists
observe as I attempt to observe, and make consistent, my belief system :]
this is justificaiton for me not enjoying mushrooms but still liking my veggies
a black woman invented the telescope
